content:
Emily Riehl exemplifies decategorization decategorification by restricting SetSetSet to Finiso\text{Fin}_{iso}Finiso​, finite Sets and their bijections, and then defining the cardinality Functor ∣−∣:Finiso→N|-| : \text{Fin}_{iso} \rightarrow \mathbb N∣−∣:Finiso​→N treating N\mathbb NN as a discrete category. Essentially mapping the category of isomorphic sets to their skeleton.

She explains natural transformations, like A×B≅B×AA \times B \cong B \times AA×B≅B×A, get mapped to equations between natural numbers, like ab=baab = baab=ba

But if N\mathbb NN is a discrete category, it doesn't have (categorical) products right? So in what sense are the products from Set getting carried over?

Emily's example for context:
1be8b34d-18a0-4720-8886-ae11eb94f9c7.png

It's decategorification, not "decategorization".

But if N\mathbb{N}N is a discrete category, it doesn't have products right?

Right. N\mathbb{N}N does not have products, which is why it's good to realize it's the decategorification of a category that does.

I'd rather think of it as a mere set than a discrete category, in what follows. Thinking of it as a discrete category is not helpful here.

So in what sense are the products from Set getting carried over?

This is how decategorification works:

Any functor F:C→DF : C \to DF:C→D between essentially small categories gives a function

Decat(F):Decat(C)→Decat(D)\mathrm{Decat}(F) : \mathrm{Decat}(C) \to \mathrm{Decat}(D)Decat(F):Decat(C)→Decat(D)

where Decat(C)\mathrm{Decat}(C)Decat(C) is the set of isomorphism classes of objects of CCC and similarly for DDD. Here's how it works:

Decat(F)([c])=[d]\mathrm{Decat}(F)([c]) = [d] Decat(F)([c])=[d]

where [c][c][c] is the isomorphism class of the object c∈Cc \in Cc∈C, and similarly for ddd.

I think from this you can figure out how decategorifying the product functor

×:FinSet×FinSet→FinSet \times : \mathsf{FinSet} \times \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}×:FinSet×FinSet→FinSet

we get the usual multiplication of natural numbers, which is

Decat(×):N×N→N \mathrm{Decat}(\times) : \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}Decat(×):N×N→N
Similarly addition comes from coproducts, and so on.

You will need to ponder Decat(FinSet×FinSet)\mathrm{Decat}(\mathsf{FinSet} \times \mathsf{FinSet})Decat(FinSet×FinSet) and simplify it a bit, to see what's going on here. More generally: given categories CCC and DDD, what's Decat(C×D)\mathrm{Decat}(C \times D)Decat(C×D)? Make the obvious guess, then prove it!
Emily is working with the groupoid of sets and bijections, which also doesn't have categorical products — but it has a monoidal product given as the cartesian product of sets.
Likewise the monoid N with multiplication is a discrete category with a monoidal product...
Emily should (in my humble opinion) be working with the category of sets and functions, so that 'products' have a nice universal property. Anyway, that's the story I was telling above.
I was more addressing @Alex Kreitzberg but it wasn't clear from your post if you were thinking about the groupoid or the category of finite sets.

I did assume he was talking about finite sets and his presentation is making sense (I'm still putting the pieces together).

When that was clear I was planning on circling back to clarifying what you pointed out, so thank you! Here decatigorification was stepping a category down to a discrete monoidal groupoid.
(if I got that last sentence right, this does seem more fussy than just saying "a set with product")

David Michael Roberts said:

I was more addressing Alex Kreitzberg but it wasn't clear from your post if you were thinking about the groupoid or the category of finite sets.

Whoops, sorry - for me FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet is the category of finite sets and functions, while something like core(FinSet)\mathrm{core}(\mathsf{FinSet})core(FinSet) or S\mathsf{S}S is the groupoid of finite sets and bijections. (S\mathsf{S}S because it's a good way of thinking of all symmetric groups SnS_nSn​ together - @Joe Moeller and @Todd Trimble have been engaged in a long detailed study of this groupoid and its offspring.)

Alex Kreitzberg said:

Here decategorification was stepping a category down to a discrete monoidal groupoid.

'Discrete monoidal groupoid' is how people say 'monoid' when they've studied too much category theory too fast and haven't recovered yet. :upside_down: Some of these people also say 'object of the category of sets' instead of 'set'.

(if I got that last sentence right, this does seem more fussy than just saying "a set with product")

A monoid is a set with an associative product and identity element, and that is essentially the same as a 'discrete monoidal category' or 'discrete monoidal groupoid'.

When you decategorify a monoidal category you get a monoid.

'Set with product' is a bit ambiguous because we're left wondering about whether it obeys the associative law and has an identity. If you don't require these, say [[magma]]. If you do, say [[monoid]].

Lemma For all categories C and D, Decat(C×D)≅Decat(C)×Decat(D)\text{Decat}(C \times D) \cong \text{Decat}(C)\times \text{Decat(D)}Decat(C×D)≅Decat(C)×Decat(D)

Proof:

First, for all c,c′∈Cc,c' \in Cc,c′∈C and d,d′∈Dd, d' \in Dd,d′∈D an object (c,d)∈C×D(c, d) \in C \times D(c,d)∈C×D is isomorphic to another object (c′,d′)∈C×D(c', d') \in C \times D(c′,d′)∈C×D exactly when we can find isomorphisms f:c→c′f : c \rightarrow c'f:c→c′ and g:d→d′g : d \rightarrow d'g:d→d′ because then and only then can we have the isomorphism (f,g):(c,d)→(c′,d′)(f, g) : (c, d) \rightarrow (c', d')(f,g):(c,d)→(c′,d′)

So (c,d)≅(c′,d′)(c, d) \cong (c', d')(c,d)≅(c′,d′) if and only if c≅c′c \cong c'c≅c′ and d≅d′d \cong d'd≅d′

Now define a function q:C×D→Decat(C)×Decat(D)q : C \times D \rightarrow Decat(C)\times Decat(D)q:C×D→Decat(C)×Decat(D) by
q(c,d)=([c],[d])q(c, d) = ([c], [d])q(c,d)=([c],[d])

The following chain of equivalences is useful:

(c,d)≅(c′,d′)⇔c≅c′ and d≅d′⇔[c]=[c′] and [d]=[d′]⇔([c],[d])=([c′],[d′])⇔q(c,d)=q(c′,d′)(c, d) \cong (c', d') \Leftrightarrow c \cong c' \text{ and } d \cong d' \Leftrightarrow [c] = [c'] \text{ and } [d] = [d'] \Leftrightarrow ([c], [d]) = ([c'], [d']) \Leftrightarrow q(c, d) = q(c', d')(c,d)≅(c′,d′)⇔c≅c′ and d≅d′⇔[c]=[c′] and [d]=[d′]⇔([c],[d])=([c′],[d′])⇔q(c,d)=q(c′,d′)

The top down direction of the logic chain implies there exists a unique qˉ:Decat(C×D)→Decat(C)×Decat(D)\bar q : Decat(C\times D) \rightarrow Decat(C) \times Decat(D)qˉ​:Decat(C×D)→Decat(C)×Decat(D) so that qˉ([(x,y)])=q(x,y) \bar q ([(x, y)]) = q(x, y)qˉ​([(x,y)])=q(x,y) for all x∈C,y∈Dx \in C, y \in Dx∈C,y∈D.

We know qˉ\bar qqˉ​ is surjective because qqq is surjective. We also now qˉ\bar qqˉ​ is injective since qqq is injective on isomorphism classes. That's proved by following the previous chain of equivalences from the bottom up.

This proves our Lemma.

So now what happens when we decatigorify FinSet\text{FinSet}FinSet?

Define 0s={}0_s = \{\}0s​={} and for all n∈Nn \in \mathbb Nn∈N define ns={1,2,…,n}n_s = \{1, 2, \ldots, n\}ns​={1,2,…,n}. Every finite set is isomorphic to one of these.

So now the following:

ns×ms={(1,1),…,(n,m)}≅nmsn_s \times m_s = \{ (1, 1), \ldots, (n, m) \}\cong nm_sns​×ms​={(1,1),…,(n,m)}≅nms​

Becomes under Decat\text{Decat}Decat, and precomposition by qˉ−1\bar q^{-1}qˉ​−1:

[ns]×N[ms]=[nms][n_s] \times_{\mathbb N} [m_s] = [nm_s][ns​]×N​[ms​]=[nms​]

But [ns]=n[n_s] = n[ns​]=n so this is just
n×m=nmn \times m = nmn×m=nm

Which is just multiplication of natural numbers.
:tada: GREAT! :tada:

By the way, if you know about coproducts, we also have

Decat(C+D)≅Decat(C)+Decat(D)\mathrm{Decat}(C + D) \cong \mathrm{Decat}(C) + \mathrm{Decat}(D)Decat(C+D)≅Decat(C)+Decat(D)

so it's all quite nice.
So is DecatDecatDecat just an ordinary functor that preserves limits and colimits?
Making it a left and right adjoint functor?

Hmm, I have no idea if it preserves limits and colimits - that sounds too good to be true, I just said products and coproducts. I'll think about it.

I guess you're thinking of Decat\mathrm{Decat}Decat as going from the category of categories to the category of sets.

It also goes from the 2-category of categories, functors and natural isomorphisms to the category of sets regarded as a discrete 2-category. This is a very useful fact: e.g. it implies that equivalent categories have isomorphic decategorifications. But this changes the meaning of your question about whether it preserves limits and colimits.
No, it doesn't preserve equalizers - at least not if we think of it going from the category of categories and functors to the category of sets and functions.
Interesting, I guess I was just trying to ask something about DecatDecatDecat to understand it better. While using it, it seemed like I wasn't using all the structure it might have.
So your added context is what I was looking for

Puzzle: find a category CCC with two objects and only two non-identity morphisms, and a functor F:C→CF: C \to CF:C→C, such that

  • the decategorification of the equalizer of FFF and 1C:C→C1_C: C \to C1C​:C→C

is not isomorphic to

  • the equalizer of Decat(F)\mathrm{Decat}(F)Decat(F) and Decat(1C)\mathrm{Decat}(1_C)Decat(1C​)

Here I'm thinking of Decat\mathrm{Decat}Decat as a functor from the 1-category Cat\mathsf{Cat}Cat to the 1-category Set\mathsf{Set}Set, which is not really ideal.
(For anyone who wants a puzzle.)

puzzle solution:

Define a category CCC with two objects and an isomorphism between them. Define FFF to swap the objects, and the components of the isomorphism.

Now 1C1_C1C​ and FFF disagree on every input, so their equalizer is the empty category, which decatigorifies to the empty set.

Both Decat(F)Decat(F)Decat(F) and Decat(1C)Decat(1_C)Decat(1C​) are maps from a singleton set to itself, which makes them both the identity function. So their equalizer is just the singleton set.

The singleton set isn't isomorphic to the empty set.

Great! I believe this is the simplest counterexample to show Decat\mathsf{Decat}Decat doesn't preserve limits, at least when we think of it as going from the mere 1-category of categories to Set\mathsf{Set}Set.
If we work with the 2-category of categories, functors and natural isomorphisms, and replace the concept of 'limit' by the subtler 2-categorical concept of limit, things may work out better.

I think I confused the story.

In the original example DecatDecatDecat also didn't preserve limits, because ×N\times_{\mathbb N}×N​ wasn't a categorical product, it's a monoidal product. So DecatDecatDecat is a monoidal functor.

But N\mathbb NN is a ring, which I imagine categorifies to a fancier definition than a monoidal category. So DecatDecatDecat is a bit better then that.

So maybe "does it preserve limits?" doesn't make sense? For the same reason it doesn't make sense to say ×N\times_{\mathbb N}×N​ is a product, the are no arrows in N\mathbb NN.

I'll think about how DecatDecatDecat is a Functor between 2-categories.

Or wait, maybe I'm level slipping.

Maybe we can say the products between categories gets sent to a product between sets, instead of the product within the category SetSetSet being sent to Natural number's multiplication?

I needed to get this out before I went to sleep, tomorrow I'll try to draw a picture of everything I guess :joy:
Maybe reread what I wrote?
I'm sorry which part?

Well, you're saying some curious things like this:

Alex Kreitzberg said:

In the original example Decat\mathrm{Decat}Decat also didn't preserve limits, because ×N\times_{\mathbb N}×N​ wasn't a categorical product, it's a monoidal product. So Decat\mathrm{Decat}Decat is a monoidal functor.

In the first argument, a categorical product between categories was sent to a categorical product of sets. At that level products are preserved but not limits, at least when talking about 1-categories.

But I thought we were trying to understand how natural transformations between Set endofunctors stepped down to equations between natural numbers.

I'm getting confused with the relationship between the two.

Maybe I'm getting confused with Reihl's presentation again? Because I'm substituting in her Functor from SetisoSet_{iso}Setiso​ to N\mathbb{N}N, with DecatDecatDecat but they really aren't the same?
No they can't be the same
Okay, I'm going to try to understand the way DecatDecatDecat is a Functor between 2-categories
I shouldn't post anything when I'm hallucinating at 1 in the morning :upside_down:

Okay, we have a 2-Category of Categories, Functors and natural isomorphisms

Decat steps this down to a 2-Category of Sets, functions, and function equality.

We've already explored a little bit how this works on objects and Functors. So now we should show natural isomorphisms map to equalities under DecatDecatDecat.

Suppose we have two Functors F:C→DF:\mathcal C\rightarrow \mathcal DF:C→D and G:C→DG:\mathcal C\rightarrow \mathcal DG:C→D

And a natural isomorphism between them F≅GF\cong GF≅G. Then for each c∈Cc\in \mathcal Cc∈C their outputs are isomorphic F(c)≅G(c)F(c)\cong G(c)F(c)≅G(c).

I don't think I showed this earlier, but isomorphisms are preserved by functors, therefore isomorphic inputs map to isomorphic outputs; Hence, Decat taking Functors to functions between isomorphism classes is well defined.

In any case F(c)≅G(c)F(c)\cong G(c)F(c)≅G(c) implies f([c])=g([c])f([c])=g([c])f([c])=g([c]) for all c∈Cc\in \mathcal Cc∈C, so f=gf=gf=g, where f=Decat(F)f=Decat(F)f=Decat(F) and g=Decat(G)g=Decat(G)g=Decat(G)

Finally, this shows that if you know A×(B+C)≅(A×B)+(A×C)A\times (B+C)\cong (A\times B)+(A\times C)A×(B+C)≅(A×B)+(A×C) noting both sides are the images of Functors Set×Set×Set→SetSet\times Set\times Set \rightarrow SetSet×Set×Set→Set

And have all of the product and union results about Decat, then

Decat(A×(B+C)≅(A×B)+(A×C))Decat(A×(B+C))=Decat((A×B)+(A×C))Decat(A)×Decat(B+C)=Decat(A×B)+Decat(A×C)a(b+c)=ab+bc\begin{align} Decat(A\times (B+C) &\cong (A\times B)+(A\times C) )\\ Decat(A\times(B+C)) &= Decat((A\times B)+(A\times C))\\ Decat(A)\times Decat(B+C) &= Decat(A\times B) + Decat(A\times C)\\ a(b + c) &= ab + bc \end{align}Decat(A×(B+C)Decat(A×(B+C))Decat(A)×Decat(B+C)a(b+c)​≅(A×B)+(A×C))=Decat((A×B)+(A×C))=Decat(A×B)+Decat(A×C)=ab+bc​​

where Decat(A)=aDecat(A)=aDecat(A)=a, Decat(B)=bDecat(B)=bDecat(B)=b and Decat(C)=cDecat(C)=cDecat(C)=c.

Which is the desired relationship Riehl was alluding to.

Note I think I'm abusing the notation above a bit by applying DecatDecatDecat to a set, like in Decat(A)Decat(A)Decat(A), because DecatDecatDecat works on Functors and categories, not objects of a specific category, but I think if Decat(A)Decat(A)Decat(A) is read as the equivalence class of AAA then the above argument works.

An aside, I did need to reread what Baez wrote, because I read the 2-category as the category of categories, functors, and natural transformations. After getting my head sorted, even in this case I think it's possible to decatigorify to preorders and monotonic functions.

We draw an inequality between isomorphism classes if there is a monomorphism or section between representing objects. Then I think a natural (monomorphism? section?) from F to G could map to monotonic functions satisfying f≤g

Edit:

I accidentally deleted everything at one point I hope it's sorted now.

I'd appreciate feedback on the argument, I'm worried I'm level slipping somewhere
Can a server administrator restore the most recent message? Jean's suggestion helped!
If you click on «EDITED », you will see the history of the different versions of your message. Not in LaTeX though apparently.
Thank you!

An aside, I did need to reread what Baez wrote, because I read the 2-category as the category of categories, functors, and natural transformations.

Aha - yes, Decat\mathrm{Decat}Decat does not extend to a 2-functor from that 2-category to Set\mathsf{Set}Set, because two functors F,G:C→DF, G: C \to DF,G:C→D with a natural transformation between them can do different things to isomorphism classes of objects in CCC.

After getting my head sorted, even in this case I think it's possible to decategorify to preorders and monotonic functions.

How does that work?

You can collapse any category CCC to a preorder Pre(C)\mathrm{Pre}(C)Pre(C) whose elements are objects of CCC and c≤c′c \le c'c≤c′ iff there's a morphism f:c→c′f: c \to c'f:c→c′.

Any functor F:C→DF: C \to DF:C→D then gives a monotone map, let's call it

Pre(F):Pre(C)→Pre(D)\mathrm{Pre}(F): \mathrm{Pre}(C) \to \mathrm{Pre}(D)Pre(F):Pre(C)→Pre(D),

in an evident way. We can show Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre thus defined is a functor from the category of categories to the category of preorders.

But if there's a natural transformation α:F→G\alpha : F \to Gα:F→G we don't usually have Pre(F)=Pre(G)\mathrm{Pre}(F) = \mathrm{Pre}(G)Pre(F)=Pre(G). What we instead get is

Pre(F)≤Pre(G)\mathrm{Pre}(F) \le \mathrm{Pre}(G)Pre(F)≤Pre(G)

Here I'm using the fact that given two monotone maps between preorders, say f,g:P→Qf, g: P \to Qf,g:P→Q, we can define f≤gf \le gf≤g to mean

∀p∈Pf(p)≤g(p)\forall p \in P \quad f(p) \le g(p)∀p∈Pf(p)≤g(p)

Using this we see that there's not just a set of monotone maps between preorders, but a preorder of them.

And using this we get a 2-category Preord\mathbf{Preord}Preord of preorders, monotone maps, and ≤\le ≤ relations between monotone maps!

And if I'm not screwing up, we can extend Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre as defined so far to a 2-functor

Pre:Cat→Preord\mathrm{Pre} : \mathbf{Cat} \to \mathbf{Preord} Pre:Cat→Preord
Is that what you were talking about?

I thought of that initially, but I was worried the choice of c→c′c\rightarrow c'c→c′ if and only if c≤c′c \le c'c≤c′, was somehow too permissive.

Because then in SetSetSet you have two way inequalities between every nonempty set. And one from the empty set to every other set.

So you can only tell whether a set is empty or not right?

So I was wondering if there was a principled way to choose a functor across all categories, which for the case of SetSetSet mapped to Natural numbers with the usual ordering.

That's why I was trying to restrict the categories to their subcategories of monomorphisms or sections (I hope that makes sense).

(that is, I'm not sure the sections or monomorphisms by themselves form categories, I think the monomorphisms might...)

If f,gf,gf,g are monomorphisms, then f g x=f g yf\, g \, x = f\, g\, yfgx=fgy implies g x=g y g\, x = g\, ygx=gy implies x=yx = yx=y so the composition f gf\, gfg is a monomorphism

And the identity is a monomorphism, so I think the restriction of a category to those is still a category.

And then make the inequality f≤gf \leq gf≤g if and only if f→gf \rightarrow gf→g, after making the restriction to monomorphisms.
I think that'll take SetSetSet to N\mathbb NN with the usual ordering after decatigorification, but I haven't worked it out yet.

Alex Kreitzberg said:

I thought of that initially, but I was worried the choice of c→c′c\rightarrow c'c→c′ if and only if c≤c′c \le c'c≤c′, was somehow too permissive.

I think you're imposing your taste on the math instead of letting the math tell you what it wants. Mathematics really loves the 2-functor Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre that I described. I could explain why. But let's solve your problem.

Because then in Set\mathsf{Set}Set you have two way inequalities between every nonempty set. And one from the empty set to every other set. [...] That's why I was trying to restrict the categories to their subcategories of monomorphisms or sections (I hope that makes sense).

So you're saying that the category of sets and functions give you a very boring preorder if you apply the 2-functor Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre I described. True. For But if you want a more interesting preorder, just apply Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre to the category of sets and injective functions.

And notice this is something you can do quite generally. Given a category CCC, you can define a new category Mono(C)\mathrm{Mono}(C)Mono(C) with the same objects but only monomorphisms as morphisms. Then you can apply Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre to this.

In other words: instead of discarding a beautiful tool because you don't like what it does in one particular example, notice that there's another tool available, and you can use that one first.

Okay, very cool. I'll try to quiet my mind and listen to what math is trying to tell me.

It's cool (and kinda funny) that PrePrePre is directly useful for the problem I was trying to understand :joy:. That's good marketing!

I can't resist saying a bit more. The category Set\mathsf{Set}Set has a baby sister called Boole\mathsf{Boole}Boole with just two objects, FFF and TTT. There's a functor Set→Boole\mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{Boole}Set→Boole that sends empty sets to FFF and nonempty ones to TTT. This functor is symmetric monoidal in two ways: it sends coproduct to "or" and product to "and".

In enriched category theory, a Set\mathsf{Set}Set-enriched category is just a category, since it has a set of morphisms from any object to any other. A Boole\mathsf{Boole}Boole-enriched category is a preorder, since it has a truth value of morphisms from any object to any other.

The functor Set→Boole\mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{Boole}Set→Boole I mentioned can be used to do base change. In this example, base change turns any Set\mathsf{Set}Set-enriched category to a Boole\mathsf{Boole}Boole-enriched category, by turning the hom-sets into hom-truth values. And this base change process is just what I've been calling Pre:Cat→Preord\mathrm{Pre} : \mathbf{Cat} \to \mathbf{Preord}Pre:Cat→Preord.
This is why Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre is so beautiful: this process for turning categories into preorders emerges automatically from the simpler process of turning sets into truth values.

I'm going to respond to what you posted after thinking carefully about it, but before moving on from DecatDecatDecat to Pre\textrm{Pre}Pre, I wanted to clarify something.

There are a lot of products in our example and it's making me fidgety. Specifically we have three, we have ×Cat \times_{Cat} ×Cat​ (I don't know what category this is an arrow in), ×Set:Set×CatSet→Set\times_{Set} : Set \times_{Cat} Set \rightarrow Set×Set​:Set×Cat​Set→Set, and ×N:N×SetN→N\times_\mathbb N : \mathbb N \times_{Set} \mathbb N \rightarrow \mathbb N×N​:N×Set​N→N

Now DecatDecatDecat takes ×Set:Set×CatSet→Set\times_{Set} : Set \times_{Cat} Set \rightarrow Set×Set​:Set×Cat​Set→Set to ×N:N×SetN→N\times_\mathbb N : \mathbb N \times_{Set} \mathbb N \rightarrow \mathbb N×N​:N×Set​N→N

So Decat(Set×CatSet)=N×SetNDecat(Set \times_{Cat} Set) = \mathbb N \times_{Set} \mathbb NDecat(Set×Cat​Set)=N×Set​N taking the categorical product to the set product. So it preserves products when we pay attention to what DecatDecatDecat does on objects.

DecatDecatDecat also operates on the Functor ×Set\times_{Set}×Set​, explicitly Decat(×Set)=×NDecat(\times_{Set}) = \times_\mathbb NDecat(×Set​)=×N​

I interpreted that last equality to mean DecatDecatDecat was monoidal, because it took the tensor product ×Set\times_{Set}×Set​ to the monoid product ×N\times_\mathbb N×N​, is "monoidal functor" the right terminology here?

Does that all look correct?

And if that is correct, waaaay back when you wrote Decat(C+D)≅Decat(C)+Decat(D)Decat(C + D) \cong Decat(C) + Decat(D)Decat(C+D)≅Decat(C)+Decat(D) Was that + on the left on categories, and the + on the right on Sets?
Doesn't +Set:Set×CatSet→Set+_{Set} : Set \times_{Cat} Set \rightarrow Set+Set​:Set×Cat​Set→Set map to +N:N×N→N+_{\mathbb N} : \mathbb N \times \mathbb N \rightarrow \mathbb N+N​:N×N→N?

Alex Kreitzberg said:

There are a lot of products in our example and it's making me fidgety. Specifically we have three, we have ×Cat \times_{Cat} ×Cat​ (I don't know what category this is an arrow in),

You introduced this notation, and it sounds like you're asking us to guess exactly what you mean by it - which is extra fun because you say you don't know! :upside_down:

I can't tell whether this increases our chance of giving you an answer you consider correct, or decreases it. But I will rise to this challenge:

You may recall we discussed Decat\text{Decat}Decat as a 2-functor

Decat:Catg→Set\text{Decat} : \mathbf{Cat}_g \to \mathbf{Set} Decat:Catg​→Set

where Catg\mathbf{Cat}_gCatg​ is the 2-category of categories, functors and natural isomorphisms (this is Steve Lack's notation, I'm not wedded to it), and Set\mathbf{Set}Set is the 2-category of sets, functions, and identity 2-morphisms between functions.

I asked you to show

Decat(C×D)≃Decat(C)×Decat(D) \text{Decat}(C \times D) \simeq \text{Decat}(C) \times \text{Decat}(D) Decat(C×D)≃Decat(C)×Decat(D)

for any categories C,DC, DC,D, and you happily did it.

And here's the point: the ×\times× at left is the product in Catg\mathbf{Cat}_gCatg​, while the ×\times× at right is the product in Set\mathbf{Set}Set.

So I'm guessing that your new symbol ×Cat\times_{Cat}×Cat​ means the product in Catg\mathbf{Cat}_gCatg​, while your ×Set\times_{Set}×Set​ means the product in Set\mathbf{Set}Set.

That is how I understood ×Cat\times_{Cat}×Cat​ I didn't know what to put after the colon, ×Cat:(Cat,Cat)→Cat\times_{Cat} : (Cat, Cat) \rightarrow Cat×Cat​:(Cat,Cat)→Cat feels weirdly recursive somehow. That's all that parenthetical was intended to convey.

This seems to make your various formulas be correct, e.g.

×Set:Set×CatSet→Set\times_{Set} : Set \times_{Cat} Set \rightarrow Set×Set​:Set×Cat​Set→Set

says that the product in Set\mathbf{Set}Set is a 2-functor from the category Set×Set\mathbf{Set} \times \mathbf{Set}Set×Set, defined as a product in Catg\mathbf{Cat}_gCatg​, to the category Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

And if that is correct, waaaay back when you wrote Decat(C+D)≅Decat(C)+Decat(D)Decat(C + D) \cong Decat(C) + Decat(D)Decat(C+D)≅Decat(C)+Decat(D) Was that + on the left on categories, and the + on the right on Sets?

Yes indeed. If I were feeling like a smart-aleck I'd say "what else could it possibly be? - that's the only thing that parses!"

CCC and DDD are categories, i.e. objects of Catg\mathbf{Cat}_gCatg​, while Decat(C)\mathrm{Decat}(C)Decat(C) and Decat(D)\mathsf{Decat}(D)Decat(D) are sets, i.e. objects of Set\mathbf{Set}Set. We always take products in the category or 2-category where our objects actually live.

By the way, I should assert this claim:

The 2-functor Decat:Catg→Set\text{Decat} : \mathbf{Cat}_g \to \mathbf{Set}Decat:Catg​→Set preserves products and coproducts.

This claim implies

Decat(C×D)≃Decat(C)×Decat(D) \text{Decat}(C \times D) \simeq \text{Decat}(C) \times \text{Decat}(D) Decat(C×D)≃Decat(C)×Decat(D)

and

Decat(C+D)≃Decat(C)+Decat(D) \text{Decat}(C + D) \simeq \text{Decat}(C) + \text{Decat}(D) Decat(C+D)≃Decat(C)+Decat(D)

but also more (as you'll see from the definition of 'co/product preserving functor').

Alex Kreitzberg said:

Doesn't +Set:Set×CatSet→Set+_{Set} : Set \times_{Cat} Set \rightarrow Set+Set​:Set×Cat​Set→Set map to +N:N×N→N+_{\mathbb N} : \mathbb N \times \mathbb N \rightarrow \mathbb N+N​:N×N→N?

Yes indeed! Here +N+_{\mathbb{N}}+N​ is ordinary addition of natural numbers, which is not a coproduct. So we say that the addition of natural numbers comes from decategorifying the coproduct of finite sets. Similarly multiplication of natural numbers comes from decategorifying the product of finite sets!

I love how the various levels of multiplication - multiplication of natural numbers, product of sets and product of categories - interact with each other, with each relying on the next one. This is an example of the [[microcosm principle]].

And it goes on forever: for example, the product in Catg\mathsf{Cat}_gCatg​ gives a 2-functor

×:Catg×Catg→Catg \times: \mathsf{Cat}_g \times \mathsf{Cat}_g \to \mathsf{Cat}_g ×:Catg​×Catg​→Catg​

where the times symbol in the expression Catg×Catg\mathsf{Cat}_g \times \mathsf{Cat}_g Catg​×Catg​ is the product in the 3-category of 2-categories! (You can use a 2-category or even a 1-category of 2-categories if you prefer, but the mathematics has a certain desire to keep escalating.)

Alex Kreitzberg said:

Okay, so we never use that DecatDecatDecat preserves coproducts to prove the natural number equations come from decatigorifying the natural isomorphisms then.

Right, there's an interesting asymmetry! You might think products and coproducts are perfectly symmetrical, we use products to describe binary operations, even coproducts! E.g.
coproduct of sets defines a functor

+:Set×Set→Set + : \mathsf{Set} \times \mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{Set}+:Set×Set→Set

not

+:Set+Set→Set + : \mathsf{Set} + \mathsf{Set} \to \mathsf{Set}+:Set+Set→Set

We can try to repair this asymmetry in various ways, but that's another story for another evening.

Alex Kreitzberg said:

Just one last question....

I bet you're going to break that promise someday. :wink:

can I say that DecatDecatDecat is monoidal because it sends a tensor product to a monoid?

Yikes! I get what you mean, but let's say it right:

  1. The 2-functor Decat:Catg→Set\text{Decat} : \mathbf{Cat}_g \to \mathbf{Set}Decat:Catg​→Set preserves products.
  2. Any 2-category with products is an example of a [[monoidal 2-category]], and it's a theorem that any product preserving 2-functor is a monoidal 2-functor.
  3. So, Decat:Catg→Set\text{Decat} : \mathbf{Cat}_g \to \mathbf{Set}Decat:Catg​→Set is a monoidal 2-functor. But this statement is wimpy and weak compared to 1.
  4. A monoidal 2-functor maps monoidal objects (usually called [[pseudomonoids]]) to monoidal objects.
  5. So, Decat:Catg→Set\text{Decat} : \mathbf{Cat}_g \to \mathbf{Set}Decat:Catg​→Set maps monoidal objects in Catg\mathbf{Cat}_gCatg​ to monoidal objects in Set\mathbf{Set}Set
  6. A monoidal object in Catg\mathbf{Cat}_gCatg​ is a [[monoidal category]]. A monoidal object in Set\mathbf{Set}Set is a [[monoid]].
  7. So, Decat:Catg→Set\text{Decat} : \mathbf{Cat}_g \to \mathbf{Set}Decat:Catg​→Set maps monoidal categories to monoids!

And this is how multiplication of natural numbers emerges from product of finite sets! Now you can really see how all the levels are interacting.

Woooow, okay cool. Believe it or not, that is all making sense (though it's clear to really get it I need to walk down each level manually)

You have a good evening, thank you for your time.

Great! Yes, it's easy to get lost among these levels, especially since they all look so similar... but that's actually one reason this subject is fun: it all makes perfect sense eventually and you feel like a 'master of many levels'.

Another perspective on this is that in FinSetiso\mathsf{FinSet}_{iso}FinSetiso​ we have a morphism A×B→B×AA\times B \to B\times AA×B→B×A which must be carried by F:FinSetiso→NF:\mathsf{FinSet}_{iso}\to\mathbb NF:FinSetiso​→N to a morphism in N\mathbb NN (since it's a functor). But here we only have identities; so we must assert that F(A×B)=F(B×A)F(A\times B) = F(B\times A)F(A×B)=F(B×A) by lack of a better option. (This might be why Emily doesn't work with FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet directly, as a functor FinSet→N\mathsf{FinSet}\to\mathbb NFinSet→N would be constant.)
This is something that systematically happens in decategorification: what was an nnn-morphism at one level must become an identity (equality) one level down, due to the lack of non-identities.

That makes me think of Pre(Iso(SetFin))=N\mathrm{Pre}(\mathrm{Iso}(\mathrm{Set}_{\mathrm{Fin}})) = \mathbb NPre(Iso(SetFin​))=N using Baez's preorder functor.

This is a good moment to call out, in Riehl's original example, she defined a cardinality Functor ∣⋅∣:Setiso→N|\cdot| : \mathrm{Set}_{\mathrm{iso}} \rightarrow \mathbb N∣⋅∣:Setiso​→N which is a morphism in Cat\mathrm{Cat}Cat, but Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre and Decat\mathrm{Decat}Decat are both morphisms in 2Cat\mathrm{2Cat}2Cat.

If the goal is to understand Decatigorification beyond just Set\mathrm{Set}Set, then it makes more sense to talk about Decat\mathrm{Decat}Decat and Pre\mathrm{Pre}Pre, so I get the motivation behind Baez's shift in focus.

Though I suppose Riehl was trying to avoid talking about 2-categories, since her goal here was to show off how nifty natural transformations are.

note: I don't really fully understand pseudofunctors but I get the motivation.

The relationships here seem innocuous but I'm worried that if I trip I'll fall off a cliff.

Why is it safe to work with strict 2-Functors and strict 2-categories generally? Is it true I need Pseudofunctors to get these Functors to be "the same", and therefore I need bicategories? Am I overthinking this?

Every bicategory is equivalent to a strict 2-category - this is a souped-up version of Mac Lane's strictification theorem saying every monoidal category is equivalent to a strict monoidal category.

However, the equivalence here is not a strict 2-functor.

There's a lot more to say about this, but you've convinced me that Pre ∘\circ∘ core and Decat are equivalent if we set up the machinery intelligently (e.g., not more strict than it should be, etc.).
